quiz.title: Unit 4: Forces (Quiz 5)
quiz.subtitle: Newton's Second and Third Laws (10 Questions)
quiz.subject: Physics

questions.question: A $3.0\text{ kg}$ object accelerates at $4.0\text{ m/s}^2$ to the right. If one force is $14\text{ N}$ to the right, the other force must be:
questions.explanation: $F_{net} = ma = 3.0 \times 4.0 = 12$ N right. $F_{net} = 14 + F_2$ â‡’ $F_2 = -2$ N (2 N left).

questions.question: An object has a mass of $10\text{ kg}$ on Earth ($g \approx 9.8\text{ m/s}^2$). What is its weight?
If a $10\text{ kg}$ object is moved to the Moon (where $g \approx 1.6\text{ m/s}^2$), which of the following is true?
options: Its mass decreases, but its weight stays the same.
Its mass stays the same, but its weight decreases.
Both mass and weight stay the same.
questions.explanation: Mass is intrinsic property (stays same). Weight = mg depends on gravity, so decreases on Moon.

questions.question: A $2.0\text{ kg}$ object is subjected to a net force of $10\text{ N}$ North. The acceleration is:
A 10 kg box is pushed to the right by a 70 N force. A 30 N force opposes the motion, acting to the left. What is the acceleration of the box?
Newton's Third Law states that whenever one object exerts a force on a second object, the second object exerts a force on the first that is:
options: Greater in magnitude and in the same direction.
Equal in magnitude and in the same direction.
Equal in magnitude and in the opposite direction.
Smaller in magnitude and in the opposite direction.
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law: action-reaction forces are equal in magnitude and opposite in direction.

questions.question: Why do action-reaction forces NOT cancel each other out?
options: Because they are not equal in magnitude.
Because they act on different bodies.
Because they act in the same direction.
Because one of the forces is 'fictitious'.
questions.explanation: Forces cancel only when they act on the same object. Action-reaction act on different objects.

questions.question: A soccer player kicks a ball. If the 'action' is the foot pushing on the ball, the 'reaction' is:
options: The ball pushing back on the foot.
Friction between the foot and the ground.
questions.explanation: Reaction force is ball pushing back on foot (equal and opposite).

questions.question: If Object A (mass $100\text{ kg}$) and Object B (mass $1\text{ kg}$) collide, which object experiences the greater force?
options: Both experience the exact same magnitude of force.
It depends on which object was moving faster.
questions.explanation: Newton's Third Law: forces during collision are equal in magnitude on both objects.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You've mastered Newton's Second and Third Laws.
scoreMessages.70: Good work! Review the relationship between force, mass, and acceleration.
scoreMessages.50: Keep practicing. Focus on net force calculations and action-reaction pairs.
scoreMessages.0: Let's review. Study Newton's Laws and how forces interact.
